awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Understanding chemical weathering using lithium and potassium isotopes
awd_abstract_narration:
The chemical weathering or breakdown of rocks and minerals on Earth's surface transfers essential nutrients from the land surface to streams, groundwater, and eventually the oceans. Chemical weathering also consumes atmospheric CO2 and thus helps to regulate climate over millions of years, maintaining a long-term balance with volcanic emissions.  Despite significant research, the processes that control chemical weathering remain uncertain and debated. This research project seeks to develop new techniques and innovative modeling approaches to study the rate and extent of chemical weathering of rocks and minerals on the surface of the Earth.  The work will use existing knowledge of lithium isotope chemistry and will develop new knowledge in potassium isotope chemistry to measure weathering.  The work will improve our understanding of the interactions between chemical weathering and climate on geologic time scales and the flux of elements into surface waters. Students from high school to PhD-level, including those from low-income households, first-generation college students, and members of under-represented groups will be trained in modern geochemical techniques. Results will be reported in conferences and peer-reviewed journals by students and researchers and introduced into college courses.

The goals of this proposal are to advance the knowledge of Li and K isotope geochemistry and lay the foundation for using K isotopes as a new tracer of chemical weathering and especially silicate weathering. The approach is to systematically investigate Li and K isotopic variations during chemical weathering and examine the processes and mechanisms that may produce isotopic fractionation by performing laboratory experiments and studying well-characterized natural samples. Combining the development and application of the K with Li isotopes as chemical weathering proxies is the first attempt to disentangle different controls of chemical weathering in both laboratory and natural settings. Following recent studies on Li and K isotopes as weathering tracers, the PI proposes to 1) determine Li and K isotopic variation in fresh Hawaiian basalts, weathered rocks, soils, streams and ground waters; 2) quantify the magnitudes and mechanisms of Li and K isotope fractionation during chemical weathering; and 3) investigate whether K isotopes can be combined with Li isotopes as chemical weathering tracers. The development of the Li and K isotope weathering proxy will greatly enhance the understanding of chemical weathering and its impact on different tectonic and climatic factors.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

Our research has broken new ground in the field of geochemistry by focusing on the underexplored area of potassium isotope behavior during chemical weathering. Prior to our work, the Li isotope had been established as a proxy for understanding the impacts of various tectonic and climatic factors on chemical weathering. However, the interpretive framework for this proxy was still a matter of debate, and potassium isotope geochemistry was nascent, with limited existing peer-reviewed publications on K isotopes' behavior during chemical weathering.

Through our pioneering method that combines K with Li isotopes as chemical weathering proxies, we made the first attempt to disentangle different controls of chemical weathering in both laboratory and natural settings. Our findings have significantly contributed to the understanding of isotope fractionation during chemical weathering, demonstrating that, similar to Li, K isotopes exhibit limited fractionation during the dissolution of primary minerals/rocks but significant fractionation during clay sorption and the weathering of basalts. Notably, our research showed that K isotopes, unlike Li isotopes, are significantly influenced by plants during the weathering process and can, alongside Li isotopes, serve as powerful tracers for chemical weathering and for quantifying continental silicate weathering fluxes.

Broader Impacts

The project has established a cutting-edge low-temperature geochemistry program at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. It has supported one PhD student and multiple undergraduate students, including women and minorities, in conducting research within this program. The PI's successful track record of working with diverse students at UNC has continued, with undergraduate alumni from the lab presenting their research at regional and international meetings and publishing first-author peer-reviewed papers.

Moreover, the project has allowed for mentoring high school students and underrepresented groups through internships and the IDEA program, all of which has not only enriched their educational experiences but also contributed to the diversification of the Earth Science community. Results from the proposed work have been disseminated at conferences and in peer-reviewed journals by students, visiting scholars, and the PI. The findings and methodologies developed through this project are also being integrated into the PI's courses, enriching the educational experience for students, public speaking, and paving the way for future research in geochemistry.

In summary, our project has not only contributed significantly to the field of geochemistry/Earth Science by advancing the understanding of non-traditional stable isotopes (especially Li and K isotopes) as tracers of chemical weathering but has also had a profound impact on education and diversity in Earth Science. Through this work, we have laid the groundwork for future studies in this area and contributed to the training and development of the next generation of Earth and Environmental scientists.
